results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 16-18.
results.creator_credit: Mandy Smith, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: In episode 16 information is given on the workers’ rehabilitation program, as well as helpful advice on activities people can perform at home to alleviate repetitive strain injury. Episode 17 stresses the importance of effective occupational health and safety procedures in the workplace. And in “Solving problems at work”, examples are dramatised on how best to facilitate discussion between employees and employers.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 13-15.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mandy Smith, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: In “Communicating change” issues of both coping with change in the workplace and change in personal relationships are addressed. Episode 14, “Planning for your retirement” answers some of the most frequent questions asked about superannuation. And in “Resolving conflicts” the Victorian Building Industries Agreement is examined as evidence of the importance of regular contact, negotiation and consultation between employers, trade unions and employees/members.

results.title: Encounters with whales
results.creator_credit: Chris Strewe, Ross Isaacs and Ocean Planet Images
results.brief_description: Tina Dalton dedicates this film “to the gentle leviathans of the sea, whose beauty and innocence have awakened me.” Aboard the Tall Ship “Anna Kristina”, a team of scientists and Tina observe and interact with Humpback Whales of Platypus Bay. This video captures rare images of these giants, leaping out of the water in a spectacular display of strength and grace, interacting with Tina in a special show of trust and males fighting for mating supremacy. Share the joy with a team of rescuers as they save a stranded whale.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 10-12.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: The first episode on this video is “Using electronic banking” and it explains the convenience and uses of modern ATMs (automatic teller machines). Episode eleven, “Retraining at work” contains a drama set in an iron factory to detail the advantages of retraining for both young and not-so-young workers. In “Using electricity safely” helpful hints and advice are given on how to protect oneself from electrocution, and the importance of ensuring your home or workplace has no faulty electrical wiring.

results.title: Encounter at Kwacha House - Halifax
results.creator_credit: Rex Tasker, Barrie Howells, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A vociferous discussion between black and white youths at the interracial club in Halifax, touching on racial discrimination in employment, housing, education and interpersonal relations.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 1-3.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: A series of videos examining the changing nature of work in contemporary Australian society and primarily aimed at audiences from non-English speaking backgrounds. In episode 1, “Improving your skills”, Rosa undertakes English classes to learn to read and write, and in the long term, to be able to take further courses to improve her skills. In “Finding a career” Trahn is encouraged by a work friend to learn English and find work similar to the job he left in Vietnam. In “Looking to the future” workers on a building site discuss the long-term importance of superannuation.

results.title: Energy Victoria
results.brief_description: A brief promotional overview of the corporate activities of Energy Victoria. Services highlighted are those which assist clients to conserve energy and allow for the development of renewable resources. There is no dialogue but the images are accompanied by a soundtrack.

results.title: Energy management for the future
results.creator_credit: Michael Melnyk, Patrick Loubert, Melvana Communications Group and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Our society is rapidly depleting its energy bank. This film creates awareness of the seriousness of the situation, what measures the federal government has taken, and how each one of us can help slow down the rapid consumption of non-renewable resources.

results.title: Enemy alien
results.creator_credit: Jeanette Lerman, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is about a people who dared to ask: “What are they going to do with us?” The Japanese-Canadians fought long and hard to be accepted as Canadians. It is important that the long story of frustration and injustice, mistrust and hate, and eventual triumph should be remembered. This film tells that story. (Awards: New York; Birmingham.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeanette Lerman, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: End game in Paris
results.creator_credit: Veronika Soul, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An adaptation of a segment of Ian Adam’s novel ‘End Game in Paris’, this film concerns a man’s search for his double. The man, a freelance photographer recently returned from Saigon, discovers that his life is being threatened. Filmmaker Veronika Soul experiments with sound and image to create a tense, enigmatic drama in which the audience is walked along a thin edge. Camera by Wolf Koenig. (Awards: Yorkton)
